title: 107_hr5608
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Wildlife Disease Testing Acceleration Act of 2002" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines "chronic wasting disease" as a transmissible nervous system disease affecting deer and elk, and "epizootic hemorrhagic disease" as a viral disease afflicting deer and other wild ruminants. The Act defines "epizootic hemorrhagic disease" as an insect-borne viral disease causing spontaneous hemorrhaging in animals. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, and "Task Force" refers to the Interagency Task Force on Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease. SEC. 3. CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE SAMPLING GUIDELINES AND TESTING PROTOCOL. The Secretary will issue guidelines for collecting animal tissue for chronic wasting disease testing, including stabilization procedures and updates. A testing protocol for laboratory assessment of potentially contaminated tissue will also be issued. Additionally, a laboratory certification and inspection program will be established. The Secretary will establish a laboratory certification and inspection program for testing chronic wasting disease in Federal and non-Federal laboratories, including private ones. Private lab test results may need verification by Federal labs. Additionally, the Secretary will expedite research into developing animal tests for the disease. The Secretary will establish a program for testing chronic wasting disease in labs, including private ones. This includes developing animal tests for live animals and field diagnostic tests, as well as testing protocols to reduce processing time. The Secretary will establish an interagency task force on epizootic hemorrhagic disease. The Federal interagency task force, known as the Interagency Task Force on Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease, is established to prevent outbreaks of the disease in the United States. It includes members such as the Secretary, Secretary of the Interior, Secretary of Commerce, Secretary of Health and Human Services, Secretary of the Treasury, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Director of the National Institutes of Health, Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and Commissioner of Customs. The Interagency Task Force on Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease, established to prevent outbreaks in the US, will submit a report to Congress within 60 days of enactment. The report will describe prevention activities and include recommendations for legislation or regulations to prevent disease outbreaks and transmission to livestock. The Interagency Task Force on Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease will report to Congress on prevention activities and recommendations for legislation to prevent disease outbreaks and transmission to livestock. Coordination of surveillance and diagnostic testing for related diseases in the United States is also a key focus. The Secretary may use available funds for administrative purposes to carry out the Act.
